p: The extensive literature available about the bioactivity of RA reflects it has been the subject of considerable study [ 81, 82]. Due to its antioxidant, antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, antimutagenic, antiviral, anti-allergic, and anticancer activities, RA is used to treat peptic ulcers, arthritis, cataracts, cancer, rheumatoid arthritis, and bronchial asthma, among other illnesses [ 65]. The biological activities of RA have led to another use, mainly in Japan, as a food preservative to extend the shelf life of fresh seafood [ 83].
